channel.title: Comments on: Book Review: Positional Judgement 1 – Territory

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Haha. He will go into further depth about topics that most people will probably never even think about it in there entire journey of go.
item.content:encoded: Haha. He will go into further depth about topics that most people will probably never even think about it in there entire journey of go.

item.description: Haha, totally and thanks Ben. Kinda make one wonder what Positional Judgement 2 will be about. :D
item.content:encoded:
Haha, totally and thanks Ben.
Kinda make one wonder what Positional Judgement 2 will be about. ðŸ˜€

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: I think Cho's book is probably the most universal book I would recommend. Jasiek's book is a lot more heavy hitting and might end up being overwhelming for most people. If you're used to academic-type studying, then I think you would be able to survive Jasiek's; otherwise, it'll probably end up collecting dust due to how detailed it is. Does that make sense?
item.content:encoded: I think Cho’s book is probably the most universal book I would recommend. Jasiek’s book is a lot more heavy hitting and might end up being overwhelming for most people. If you’re used to academic-type studying, then I think you would be able to survive Jasiek’s; otherwise, it’ll probably end up collecting dust due to how detailed it is. Does that make sense?

item.title: By: pollylop
item.dc:creator: pollylop
item.description: Thanks for the review Ben. Is it right to infer from the comment here that you might suggest starting with Cho's book and then moving on to Jasiek's?
item.content:encoded: Thanks for the review Ben. Is it right to infer from the comment here that you might suggest starting with Cho’s book and then moving on to Jasiek’s?

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: If you like studying things like you would a textbook, then I recommend Jasiek's book. However, if you like a more general overview that's pretty short while doing a good job covering Positional Judgment, then I would choose Cho Chikun's. Does that make sense?
item.content:encoded: If you like studying things like you would a textbook, then I recommend Jasiek’s book. However, if you like a more general overview that’s pretty short while doing a good job covering Positional Judgment, then I would choose Cho Chikun’s. Does that make sense?

item.title: By: Tilwen
item.dc:creator: Tilwen
item.description: Hey. Seems like a great book to have, I am wanting these time to read something about positionnal judgement, I'm pretty sure it could help me a lot (with more focus on reading in my games, of course, but haha, I don't expect to get at pro level right now, and I still think my "brain shape (mostly, sleep) isn't at his very very best, anyway). My question is : what about the comparison with Cho Chikun's book, which one would you recommend more ?
item.content:encoded:
Hey. Seems like a great book to have, I am wanting these time to read something about positionnal judgement, I’m pretty sure it could help me a lot (with more focus on reading in my games, of course, but haha, I don’t expect to get at pro level right now, and I still think my “brain shape (mostly, sleep) isn’t at his very very best, anyway).
My question is : what about the comparison with Cho Chikun’s book, which one would you recommend more ?
